de.upb.t2t.control

Class Transcriber

  • java.lang.Object
    • de.upb.t2t.control.Transcriber

  • public class Transcriber
extends java.lang.Object
    This is one of the application's core classes. The only public method it offers is #transcribe(String whose main purpose is to convert a given String into a series of TranscriptionSegments. These segments will hold the corresponding phonetic transcription of said string and will be displayed inside the MainTranscriptionPane.outputField. All other methods within this class simply provide supportive functionality for the transcription process.
    Author:
    Michel May (michel-may@gmx.de)
    See Also:
    transcribe(String)

    • Method Detail

      • addSegmentToListAndMainPane

        private static void addSegmentToListAndMainPane(TranscriptionSegment finishedSegment,
                                                java.util.List<TranscriptionSegment> finishedSegments)
        A convenience method that adds the given segment both to the given list, but also to the MainTranscriptionPane.outputField. For the latter, the JavaFx Application Thread is called.
        Parameters:
        finishedSegment - the segment to add to both lists.
        finishedSegments - the working list to add the segment to.

      • getLastSegment

        private static TranscriptionSegment getLastSegment(java.util.List<TranscriptionSegment> list)
        A convenience function to retrieve the last element of a List of TranscriptionSegments, just as Stack.peek() would. Additionally, any potential IndexOutOfBoundsException is caught and null returned instead.
        Parameters:
        list - the list to retrieve the last element from.
        Returns:
        the last element of the list; null if the list was empty.

      • isSingularExpression

        private static boolean isSingularExpression(java.lang.String string)
        Evaluates whether the given String equals an expression that would require any following word, e.g. a currency character, to be in the singular. Its primary use is to prepare the transcription of any special character that needs to be replaced by the application prior to transcription. Examples for such expressions are "one", "a", "1", etc.
        Parameters:
        string - the String to evaluate.
        Returns:
        true if the given String equals a singular expresion; false otherwise.
        See Also:
        CurrencyCharacter

      • stringEndsWithMinusCharacter

        private static boolean stringEndsWithMinusCharacter(java.lang.String string)

        A simple convenience function to check whether the given String ends with a minus character. If so then the minus would require to be transcribed, of course.

        Impotant: Please note that there are roughly 10 UTF-8 characters that look like a minus, but in fact are not. These may be various types of dashes or hyphens. Currently, this function will only return true for the HTML entities - (hyphen minus) and − (minus sign).

        Parameters:
        string - the String to evaluate.
        Returns:
        true if the String ends with a minus character.

      • isVocalicSound

        private static boolean isVocalicSound(char c)
        A convenience function that simply checks whether the given char equals a vowel / vocalic sound. This may be important when deciding which transcription to select for example for the lemma "the".
        Parameters:
        c - the character to evaluate.
        Returns:
        true if the given character equals a vowel; false otherwise.

      • transcribe

        public void transcribe(java.lang.String input)
                throws java.io.IOException,
                       java.sql.SQLException,
                       java.lang.Exception

        This probably is the most central method in the entire application. Its use is to parse a given String and transform it into a phonetic transcription. As feedback is given to the user about the progress of the current state of the function, it should be called on a separate thread! The procedure includes the following steps which are for the sake of readability not written in pseudo-code.

        • Dealing with any potential non-word characters, such as currencies ('$', '€', ...) or numerals ('2015', '-1,234,567.89', ...), but also punctuation characters. The latter includes applying the notational delimiter elements, i.e. '/', '|' and '||'.
        • Breaking up the String into segments that can be looked up in the database.
        • Providing the corresponding transcription pieces.
        • Assigning the appropriate word class of an item. However, since this cannot be done algorithmically, in case of a conflict (e.g. "might" as a modal auxiliary vs. "might" as a common noun), the function will appropriate the respective buttons accordingly so that the user can make the choice instead.
        Parameters:
        input - The input String to transcribe.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if the instantiation of any of the TranscriptionSegments fails.
        java.sql.SQLException - if the currently used instance AbstractSQLiteBridge is of type SQLiteBridgeDesktop and something went wrong while querying the database.
        java.lang.Exception - most likely if the currently used instance AbstractSQLiteBridge throws one while querying the database.
        See Also:
        TranscriptionSegment, MainTranscriptionPane, AbstractSQLiteBridge, CurrencyCharacter, PunctuationCharacter

      • doPostProcessing

        private void doPostProcessing(java.util.List<TranscriptionSegment> finishedSegments)

        This function should only be called after the finished TranscriptionSegments have been added to the MainTranscriptionPane. It will then post process that list for user convenience by pre-selecting the most likely transcriptions, colourising potential conflicts and requesting focus on the first of these conflicts.

        Note that just like the transcribe(String) function, this should not be called on the JavaFx Application Thread!

        Parameters:
        finishedSegments - the same list object of transcription segments that was added to the main transcription pane.

      • newEnclosingDelimiterSegment

        private TranscriptionSegment newEnclosingDelimiterSegment()
                                                   throws java.io.IOException,
                                                          java.net.URISyntaxException
        Returns a new instance of a TranscriptionSegment that contains nothing transcriptionwise but the notational slash ("/") that signals the beginning and ending of a transcription.
        Returns:
        a new TranscriptionSegment containing the notational delimiting character '/'.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if the TranscriptionSegment constructor throws one.
        java.net.URISyntaxException - if TranscriptionSegment.TranscriptionSegment() throws one.

      • newInnerDelimiterSegment

        private TranscriptionSegment newInnerDelimiterSegment(java.lang.String punctuation)
                                               throws java.io.IOException,
                                                      java.net.URISyntaxException
        Returns a new instance of a TranscriptionSegment that contains nothing transcriptionwise but the notational single or double bars that indicate the original punctuation such as ".", "," or "?". The function automatically returns the appropriate element based on the given punctuation, including null if the given String does not require to be transcribed at all.
        Parameters:
        punctuation - the punctuation character.
        Returns:
        the corresponding transcription segment.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if TranscriptionSegment.TranscriptionSegment(String) throws one.
        java.net.URISyntaxException - if TranscriptionSegment.TranscriptionSegment(String) throws one.

      • findHighestPunctCharInList

        private PunctuationCharacter findHighestPunctCharInList(java.util.List<java.util.regex.MatchResult> nonWordCharacters)
        A convenience function that will run through the given list and, should there be anyone inside, return the punctuation character with the highest delimier mode. This is useful when deciding which notational bar delimiter to add ('|' vs. '||').
        Parameters:
        nonWordCharacters - list of non-word character match results from a regex search.
        Returns:
        the PunctuationCharacter with the highest delimiter mode inside the given list; null if there isn't any

      • lookUpNumeral

        private java.util.List<WordButton> lookUpNumeral(long integerPart,
                                                 java.lang.String decimalPart)
                                          throws java.lang.NumberFormatException,
                                                 java.sql.SQLException,
                                                 java.lang.Exception

        This function translates (almost) any given number into its corresponding transcription. For easier processing, the integer part of said number is given as a long (thereby predetermining the maximum range of possible number transcription), while the decimal part is a (well-formatted) String. The '.' character will automatically be added to the transcription should the decimal string not be empty. As an example, an input such as

        "12345.678" would lead to the follwing transcription: /twelv θaʊznd θriː hʌndred fɔːti faɪv dɒt sɪks sevn eɪt/

        Note that it will not take into account the special case of year numbers between 2000 and 100. These need special treatment.

        Parameters:
        integerPart - the integer part of the number to transcribe, e.g. "12345.351".
        decimalPart - the decimal part of the number to transcribe, e.g. "12345.351".
        Returns:
        a list of WordButtons that constitute the transcription.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NumberFormatException - most likely if the decimalPart String was malformed, but possibly also if anything unexpected happened while transcribing the integer part.
        java.sql.SQLException - if the currently used instance AbstractSQLiteBridge is of type SQLiteBridgeDesktop and something went wrong while querying the database.
        java.lang.Exception - most likely if the currently used instance AbstractSQLiteBridge throws one while querying the database.

      • lookUpNumeralTensAndOnes

        private java.util.List<WordButton> lookUpNumeralTensAndOnes(int num)
                                                     throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException,
                                                            java.sql.SQLException,
                                                            java.lang.Exception
        A convenience method to lookup the transcription parts of an int number on the interval of [0, 99].
        Parameters:
        num - the number to transcribe.
        Returns:
        a list of WordButtons that constitute the transcription.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the number was smaller than 0 or greater than 99.
        java.sql.SQLException - if the currently used instance AbstractSQLiteBridge is of type SQLiteBridgeDesktop and something went wrong while querying the database.
        java.lang.Exception - most likely if the currently used instance AbstractSQLiteBridge throws one while querying the database.

      • getLookupStringNumeralBelowTwenty

        private java.lang.String getLookupStringNumeralBelowTwenty(int num)
        A convenience method to fetch the String of a one-digit number for later database lookup.
        Parameters:
        num - the number whose lookup String to retrieve.
        Returns:
        the number's corresponding lookup String.

      • getLookupStringDigitArea

        private java.lang.String getLookupStringDigitArea(int digitCountFromZero)
        A convenience method to fetch the String of the current digit area for later database lookup. "Digit area" means the distance from the "dot" inside a decimal number and the corresponding name of that area. For example, a digit count of 4 to 6 would mean that the respective number is in its thousands (as in "12,345"), 7 to 9 would be in the millions, etc.
        Parameters:
        digitCountFromZero - the number of digits from zero.
        Returns:
        the corresponding digit area.
